title: 111_hr4300
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Restoring America's Commitment to Consumers Act of 2009" and includes a provision for a national credit card usury rate. Section 107 of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to establish a national consumer credit usury rate of 16 percent for credit card accounts under open end consumer credit plans. This rate includes certain fees in the annual percentage rate calculation. The Truth in Lending Act establishes a national consumer credit usury rate of 16 percent for credit card accounts under open end consumer credit plans. Fees such as membership or annual fees are included in the finance charge. The Board may adjust the maximum annual percentage rate limitation in the public interest to protect consumers from exploitive lending practices. The Truth in Lending Act sets a national consumer credit usury rate of 16 percent for credit card accounts. The Board can adjust the maximum annual percentage rate limitation to protect consumers from exploitive lending practices. An increase in the limitation must be justified by severe economic conditions, taking into account bank prime rates and relevant statistical information. The Board must notify Congress of any adjustments made. After receiving notice from the Board regarding an adjustment to the maximum annual percentage rate limitation, the House of Representatives' Committee on Financial Services must promptly conduct a hearing on the adjustment. The House rules supersede any other rule, recognizing the constitutional right to change rules. Any increase in the maximum annual percentage rate limitation has a delayed effective date. The House rules allow for changes in rules, with any increase in the maximum annual percentage rate limitation having a delayed effective date. Congress clarifies that no endorsement is made for a 16 percent credit card rate and intends for rates to be most advantageous to the borrower. The House rules allow for changes in rules regarding the maximum annual percentage rate limitation on consumer credit cards. Consumer credit card issuers are encouraged to maintain rates that are advantageous to borrowers. In the case of credit card accounts with rates below 16 percent as of December 11, 2009, any increase in the annual percentage rate is considered an unfair and deceptive act. The House rules allow for changes in rules regarding the maximum annual percentage rate limitation on consumer credit cards. For credit card accounts with rates below 16 percent as of December 11, 2009, any increase in the annual percentage rate during a specific period will be considered unfair or deceptive. A joint resolution related to this increase must meet certain criteria. The House rules allow for changes in rules regarding the maximum annual percentage rate limitation on consumer credit cards. A joint resolution disapproving any increase in the maximum annual percentage rate on credit card accounts under an open end consumer credit plan must be passed by Congress. SEC. 3. CAP ON CERTAIN CREDIT CARD ACCOUNT FEES. New section added to Chapter 3 of the Truth in Lending Act limits credit card account fees to a maximum of $15, including late fees, insufficient funds fees, overdraft fees, and over-the-limit transaction fees. The new section in Chapter 3 of the Truth in Lending Act sets a $15 limit on credit card account fees, excluding fees accounted for under section 107(f)(2). SEC. 4. CLARIFICATION OF COORDINATION WITH STATE LAW.

The first sentence of section 111(a)(1) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended by striking "the disclosure of information in connection with".

SEC. 5. EFFECTIVE DATE.

The amendments made by sections 2 and 3 shall take effect on the date of the enactment of this Act.
